Author: Benmamoun, Elabbas
Title: Inflectional and Functional Morphology: Problems of Projection, Representation and Derivation
Abstract Note: This dissertation investigates the properties of functional and inflectional categories such as tense, agreement, negation and question morphemes. Two central issues are discussed. The first issue revolves around the problem of projection, representation and derivation of these categories. The second issue focuses on the effects of the interaction between these morphemes and the categories they relate to or license (such as Negative Polarity Items, Wh-phrases, Subject agreement). Much of the data come from Standard Arabic and Moroccan Arabic in addition to English and French. Conceptual and empirical arguments are given to substantiate the claim that inflectional and functional morphemes and particularly Tense, Agreement and Negation should be projected independently of the predicate. Moreover, it is argued that, in accordance with the Strict Projectionist Hypothesis, each morpheme occupies its own independent projection. As far as the problem of derivation is concerned it is argued on conceptual grounds that derivation of inflectional categories is subject to minimality. The same categories that block derivation of inflectional morphemes seem to block other relations (binding and antecedent government) that involve maximal projections. For example, negation blocks verb movement and seems to interact with extraction and binding. This provides a general account for failure of verb movement to tense in the context of the sentential negative laa in Standard Arabic and for the same effects in the context of Neg and Qu in English. What is specific to head movement is its sensitivity to the morphological status of the intervening categories. The solutions provided to the problems of projection, representation and derivation suggest possible accounts for some asymmetries that characterize the relation between certain functional morphemes and the categories they are related to or they license. For example, it is observed that preverbal NPI subjects, argued to be licensed under Spec- head agreement, are not allowed in languages like Standard Arabic and English while they are possible in Moroccan Arabic. Similarly, extraction of subjects in English and French does not trigger Do-support and Complex Inversion while extraction of complements and adjuncts does. (Copies available exclusively from Micrographics Department, Doheny Library, USC, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0182.)

Author: Badry, Fatima
Title: Acquisition of Lexical Derivational Rules in Moroccan Arabic: Implications for the Developement of Standard Arabic as a Second Language through Literacy
Abstract Note: This research investigated the development and organization of derivational rules governing the acquisition of the lexicon in Moroccan Arabic as a native dialect. The Arabic lexicon is based on a system of underlying consonantal roots that combine with surface patterns to form most content words. The study examined the role of semantic and formal properties in the process of analyzing Arabic words into patterns and underlying roots at different developmental stages. It also addressed the question of how strategies developed by Moroccan children in learning their native dialect could be utilized in teaching Standard Arabic in a school setting. It was hypothesized that: (1) the underlying consonantal root plays a central role both semantically and morphologically in the acquisition of the Arabic lexical derivational rules; (2) Arabic speaking children develop two major derivational strategies, which are referred to here as vertical and horizontal derivations, in the process of acquiring their lexicon. To test these hypotheses a battery of tasks designed to provide linguistic evidence were administered to 40 middle-class Moroccan children, between the ages of 3;5 and 9;9, enrolled in a private school in Casablanca, Morocco. Data were collected by means of six tasks: elicited interview, story-retelling, verbal and nominal patterns production and comprehension tasks. Each child was individually tested in four sessions over a seven week period. Data were audio-recorded and later transcribed. The errors of misformed patterns and metathesis, in addition to children's ability to derive innovative forms filling lexical gaps, were interpreted as evidence that Moroccan children develop derivational rules which allow them to use the system productively around the age of 3;5. Findings supported the prediction that the process of acquiring the Arabic lexicon follows a developmental curve which consists of four main stages: (1) the child uses words as rote learned forms; (2) the child discovers that some words which express a common meaning component also share the same pattern frames. This discovery results from advanced conceptual development and an expanded input that allow him to see that newly abstracted concepts are expressed by similar frames; (3) he abstracts the shared consonantal root from several patterns derived from it and is able to coin words by a vertical derivation rule; . . . (Author's abstract exceeds stipulated maximum length. Discontinued here with permission of author.) UMI

Author: Amakhmakh, Naceur
Title: Nonlinear phonology of a Moroccan Arabic dialect
Abstract Note: This study is primarily concerned with the phonology of one Moroccan Arabic dialect, spoken in and around Sefrou in the centre of Morocco. The main goal of this dissertation is to describe several aspects of the phonology and morphology of Moroccan Arabic in terms of autosegmental phonology. The main body of the dissertation is divided into five chapters. Chapter one outlines the framework of nonlinear phonology with some of its subcomponents in which this study is undertaken, and gives a brief description of the dialect under investigation. Chapter two analyzes various assimilatory processes that target mainly coronal consonants (e.g. definite article assimilation, prefix /t- / voicing assimilation, coronal sonorant assimilation, and long-distance assimilation of fricatives). It also examines the process of labialization. Chapter three gives an acoustic correlation of pharyngealization on vowels and examines the domain of pharyngealization spread within the word with the aim of establishing whether the domain of pharyngealization spread is morphologically determined or phonologically determined. In chapter four, two morphological operations are examined (the diminutive formation and one of the broken plural patterns), following McCarthy's insight (1979, 1981) and McCarthy and Prince (1990) among others. Both these morphological operations are based on the stem mapped onto an underlying template /C$\sb\rm I$ u C$\sb2$ i C$\sb3\ \partial$ C$\sb\rm F/$ (for the diminutive) and /C$\sb\rm I$ C$\sb2$ a C$\sb3\ \partial$ C$\sb\rm F/$ (for the broken plural). Chapter five summarizes the findings of the study.

Author: Aftat, Mokhtar
Title: The Acquisition of Negation and WH-Questins in a Moroccan Arabic speaking four-year-old child
Abstract Note: A longitudinal investigation of aspects of a child's systems of Moroccan Arabic negation and wh-questions was carried out when the child was between ages 3; 0 and 4; 0. The data were based on samples of both spontaneous and elicited speech. The analysis included syntactic, semantic, functional, and cognitive aspects of language development. The results indicated that the syntax of the subject's utterances involving negation was similar to the adult model although, occasionally, she adopted grammatical strategies that resulted in unusual negative sentences. The dominant negative structure she produced was /ma — s (i)/. In her embedded sentences, she negated the matrix S in the sentence. Her negative utterances (a) negated the propositional content of affirmative sentences, (b) negated physical actions, and (c) were a comment on affirmatives. Her language functions were also similar to the adult model, and were of both a unifunctional and a multifunctional nature. These were expressed through kinesics and paralinguistic features. The subject's production of wh-questions was grammatically correct, i.e., the pattern was wh-word + S + rising intonation. Her wh-questions expressed various appropriate functions but, by the end of the study, mastery of language functions was not complete. The subject's comprehension of structures involving ask/tell + wh-word, and the conditional with wh-words were usually misinterpreted, as were some wh- words. These observed characteristics of her incomplete linguistic knowledge were explained in terms of (a) language complexity (syntactic, semantic, and functional), (b) cognitive development, and (c) communication skills. Frequency of occurrence was a minor contributing factor.
Publisher: The University of Texas at Austin

Author: Kaye, Alan S.
Title: Morphologies of Asia and Africa
Abstract Note: In 1997, Eisenbrauns published the highly-regarded two-volume Phonologies of Asia and Africa, edited by Alan Kaye with the assistance of Peter T. Daniels, and the book rapidly became the standard reference for the phonologies of the Afro-Asiatic languages. Now the concept has been extended, and Kaye has assembled nearly 50 scholars to write essays on the morphologies of the same language group. The coverage is complete, copious, and again will likely become the standard work in the field. Contributors are an international Who's Who of Afro-Asiatic linguistics, from Appleyard to Leslau to Voigt. It is with great sadness that we report the death of Alan Kaye on May 31, 2007, while these volumes were in the final stages of preparation for the press. Alan was diagnosed with bone cancer on May 1 while on research leave in the United Arab Emirates and was brought home to Fullerton by his son on May 22.
Manual Tags: LANGUAGE ARTS & DISCIPLINES / Alphabets & Writing Systems

Author: Holes, Clive; Eid, Mushira
Title: Perspectives on Arabic Linguistics V : Papers From the Fifth Annual Symposium on Arabic Linguistics
Abstract Note: The papers in the first section of this volume,'Variation in Arabic', deal with a wide range of topics: the function of Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) vs. dialect variation in political speeches, patterns of variation in concord in Cairene dialect, the extent to which Cairenes'know'MSA, and the scope of emphaticization in different dialects. In the section on'Phonological Perspectives'there are papers dealing with emphasis spread and with gemination/degemination/antigemination in Iraqi Arabic. The papers in the section on syntax, all focused on MSA and within a GB framework, discuss aspects of Arabic that are problematic for current hypotheses in linguistics, and also more traditional issues such as word order and verbal vs. nominal sentences. The last two papers represent a historical, comparative Semitic perspective: on the function of energic suffixes, and on the reconstruction of the early Arabic sounds represented by siin and šiin.
Series: Amsterdam Studies in the Theory and History of Linguistic Science. Series IV, Current Issues in Linguistic Theory
Manual Tags: vt:Arab World general; vt:linguistics/dialectology

Author: Alshutayri, A. O. O.; Atwell, E.
Title: Exploring Twitter as a Source of an Arabic Dialect Corpus
Publication Title: International Journal of Computational Linguistics (IJCL)
Abstract Note: Given the lack of Arabic dialect text corpora in comparison with what is available for dialects of English and other languages, there is a need to create dialect text corpora for use in Arabic natural language processing. What is more, there is an increasing use of Arabic dialects in social media, so this text is now considered quite appropriate as a source of a corpus. We collected 210,915K tweets from five groups of Arabic dialects Gulf, Iraqi, Egyptian, Levantine, and North African. This paper explores Twitter as a source and describes the methods that we used to extract tweets and classify them according to the geographic location of the sender. We classified Arabic dialects by using Waikato Environment for Knowledge Analysis (WEKA) data analytic tool which contains many alternative filters and classifiers for machine learning. Our approach in classification tweets achieved an accuracy equal to 79%.

Author: Kortobi, Ibtissam
Title: Gapping and VP-Deletion in Moroccan Arabic
Publication Title: Themes in Arabic and Hebrew Syntax
Abstract Note: This chapter examines the status of VP-ellipsis in Moroccan Arabic (henceforth, MA). The main issue addressed concerns the MA auxiliary kan and its English equivalent be which impose some untreated restrictions on VP-deletion. In MA, VP-deletion is always allowed when no auxiliaries are used, no matter what the tense of the sentence is. The question is what happens when auxiliaries are used. The puzzle is why VP-deletion is disallowed when VP-arguments or adjuncts are left behind. I propose that both MA and English resort to deletion of Aspect Phrase (AspP) when the presence of the aspectual marker ka-/-ing disallows VP-deletion. Evidence supplied by the distribution of place, manner, and reason adverbs, direct and indirect objects argues that what deletes after the auxiliary kan is an aspectual projection rather than VP. VP-deletion in this case is made impossible by morphological constraints imposed by kan’s complement particle ka- (ta, in some MA dialects, -ing in English). The analysis I propose here derives the restrictions on deletion with kan from independently justified morphological properties of this auxiliary. Furthermore, it explains the behavior of the similar pattern of deletion with English be...-ing. The chapter also examines other auxiliaries, in particular, the future element yadi ( and its contracted form ya), which differs from kan in that its complement cannot be deleted. I argue that this is so because the complement of yadi is an argument, albeit a propositional one, that carries a θ-role. Similar results hold for modals.
Manual Tags: vt:Maghreb; vt:syntax; vt:transcribed texts; vt:conversation/dialogue; reg:Morocco [31.46, -6.39]
